text: Awesome! Stoked to hear!

UX Researcher Tip
(Thought it might be useful)

COMMUNICATION 101: A study how people understand technology, content, and messaging for a living. During this crisis, vague messages like "Practice social distancing" will have far less impact than concrete, specific messages like "Stay at home. Get groceries once per week."

<@U010B22ESES> how are you? 
 We will need templates. I want you to prepare them.

Information for the campaign basically falls into 4 categories: facts about COVID, symptoms about COVID, efforts regarding COVID (the hotline), and prevention methods.

I will send you the indesign file we used for making the campaign I posted yesterday.

I will need you to:
1. clean it up a bit
2. come up with 4 coherent color palettes
3. make indesign templates. each category will have a separate indesign file
4. send it to me in a zip file.

I will look at it after and go from there. Would that work for you?

text: Yes
Let me see the files
Social Distancing Concepts

Please note that WHO has changed the wording from Social Distancing to Physical Distancing, so people still remain in social contact digitally. <https://amp.cnn.com/cnn/2020/03/21/opinions/physical-distancing-menjivar-foster-brand/index.html>

attachments.title: Don't call it 'social distancing'
attachments.text: Call it 'physical distancing,' instead, write UCLA sociologists Cecilia Menjívar, Jacob G. Foster and Jennie E. Brand. In a time of coronavirus we do need to stay apart physically, but that doesn't mean losing sight of our essential connections to one another and forgetting about the plight of those most vulnerable to the fraying of social bonds. It's crucial that we stay socially connected.

I think clarifying the Brief and Draft stages will improve this. As I see it, the best method to follow here is similar to the mechanics of design contests.

Content request starts a thread with a standardized brief with as much specifics, applicable venues and the campaigns timeline. Then designers can contribute their works on this thread based on the guideline. Then work is iterated on till desired product materializes. Final design choice gets expanded for different platforms and language versions then full final product gets pushed to google drive.

That will give each designer wanting to contribute a clear way of jumping into any specific campaign at any stage of the campaign.

elements.text:
I think clarifying the Brief and Draft stages will improve this. As I see it, the best method to follow here is similar to the mechanics of design contests.

Content request starts a thread with a standardized brief with as much specifics, applicable venues and the campaigns timeline. Then designers can contribute their works on this thread based on the guideline. Then work is iterated on till desired product materializes. Final design choice gets expanded for different platforms and language versions then full final product gets pushed to google drive.

That will give each designer wanting to contribute a clear way of jumping into any specific campaign at any stage of the campaign.

attachments.title: Ibuprofen, paracetamol, and steam for patients with respiratory tract infections in primary care: pragmatic randomised factorial trial
attachments.text: Objective To assess strategies for advice on analgesia and steam inhalation for respiratory tract infections. Design Open pragmatic parallel group factorial randomised controlled trial. Setting Primary care in United Kingdom. Participants Patients aged ≥3 with acute respiratory tract infections. Intervention 889 patients were randomised with computer generated random numbers in pre-prepared sealed numbered envelopes to components of advice or comparator advice: advice on analgesia (take paracetamol, ibuprofen, or both), dosing of analgesia (take as required v regularly), and steam inhalation (no inhalation v steam inhalation). Outcomes Primary: mean symptom severity on days 2-4; symptoms rated 0 (no problem) to 7 (as bad as it can be). Secondary: temperature, antibiotic use, reconsultations. Results Neither advice on dosing nor on steam inhalation was significantly associated with changes in outcomes. Compared with paracetamol, symptom severity was little different with ibuprofen (adjusted difference 0.04, 95% confidence interval −0.11 to 0.19) or the combination of ibuprofen and paracetamol (0.11, −0.04 to 0.26). There was no evidence for selective benefit with ibuprofen among most subgroups defined before analysis (presence of otalgia; previous duration of symptoms; temperature >37.5°C; severe symptoms), but there was evidence of reduced symptoms severity benefit in the subgroup with chest infections (ibuprofen −0.40, −0.78 to −0.01; combination −0.47; −0.84 to −0.10), equivalent to almost one in two symptoms rated as a slight rather than a moderately bad problem. Children might also benefit from treatment with ibuprofen (ibuprofen: −0.47, −0.76 to −0.18; combination: −0.04, −0.31 to 0.23). Reconsultations with new/unresolved symptoms or complications were documented in 12% of those advised to take paracetamol, 20% of those advised to take ibuprofen (adjusted risk ratio 1.67, 1.12 to 2.38), and 17% of those advised to take the combination (1.49, 0.98 to 2.18). Mild thermal injury with steam was documented for four patients (2%) who returned full diaries, but no reconsultations with scalding were documented. Conclusion Overall advice to use steam inhalation, or ibuprofen rather than paracetamol, does not help control symptoms in patients with acute respiratory tract infections and must be balanced against the possible progression of symptoms during the next month for a minority of patients. Advice to use ibuprofen might help short term control of symptoms in those with chest infections and in children. Trial registration [ISRCTN 38551726][1]. [1]: /external-ref?link_type=ISRCTN&access_num=ISRCTN38551726
attachments.fallback: The BMJ: Ibuprofen, paracetamol, and steam for patients with respiratory tract infections in primary care: pragmatic randomised factorial trial

attachments.title: Non-steroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs may Worsen the Course of Communi
attachments.text: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are frequently prescribed or used as self-medication in cases of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). Nevertheless, the consequences of such medication on the risk of pleuroparenchymal complications are not well known. The aim was to investigate whether exposure to NSAIDs prior to hospital admission among patients suffering from CAP is associated with the development of pleural complications or a lung abscess. All consecutive non-immunocompromised patients with CAP and admitted to a university hospital were prospectively included (2-year period). The risk of pleuropulmonary complications was analyzed according to previous exposure to NSAIDs. Of the 221 included patients, 40 (18.1%) had developed a pleuropulmonary complication. NSAIDs intake prior to admission was reported for 24 patients (10.9%) who were younger (50.6 ± 18.5 vs. 66.5 ± 16.4 years; p = 0.001), had less comorbidities (60 vs. 25.1%; p = 0.001), had a longer duration between the first symptoms of CAP and the start of an antibiotic therapy (6.1 ± 7.6 vs. 2.8 ± 3.8 days; p = 0.001), and who had a higher incidence of pleuropulmonary complications (33.3 vs. 16.2%; p = 0.048). In multivariate analyses, two factors were independently associated with the development of pleuroparenchymal complications: NSAIDs intake [Odds Ratio (OR) = 2.57 [1.02–6.64]; p = 0.049] and alcohol abuse (OR = 2.68 [1.27–5.69]; p = 0.01). Our findings suggest that NSAIDs, often taken by young and healthy patients, may worsen the course of CAP with delayed therapy and a higher rate of pleuropulmonary complications.
attachments.fallback: Lung: Non-steroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs may Worsen the Course of Communi
